channel.title: Gaming Mouse
channel.description:
I want a good, wired, gaming mouse. I prefer over (or equal to,) 1800 dpi, must be less than $50. What do some of you guys have? I'm using a wireless Logitech generic that won't tell me what it is at the moment.
EDIT: [url='https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16826153055']Really liking the Death Adder.[/url]

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: garrthbarrttinn
item.description:
I withdraw my recommendation on getting the mouse I suggested earlier. I switched it with my friend’s slightly better mouse for a while and was wayyyyyyyy more accurate. I think I’ll buy a death adder now.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: Bloodshot
item.description:
If you’re still looking i would recommend the logitech g9 - as someone mentioned earlier it has 3200 dpi and it is $20 over your price range, but it is well worth it. Its the best gaming laser mouse i ever had.

https://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Programmable-Laser-Gaming-Precision/dp/B001NTFATI/ref=dp_ob_title_ce

That one is a newer model.

Read full topic

item.description:
I have an Logitech MX18 to. Never had a problem with it. It works perfect. Highly recommended

And its awful, makes ur hand sweat like hell, rubber pads under the mouse are crap. the only cool thing about it is the useless leds on both side, u can change their color.

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: BaTz281
item.description:
Harry-UK:

The MX518

A fantastic little mouse; and it’s cheap.

Mith:

this

had an old mx310 that lasted for 7 years without a single problem, and when it finally broke it was just the chord that was falling apart, internally it was actually pretty solid still (inb4 sersoft you should’ve fixed it)

went through a ton of shitty mouses that broke in a few months, and now i’ve had a mx518 for 6 months and it’s as good as the first day i bought it

also it has these buttons to adjust sensitivity which are pretty cool but i don’t really use it tbh

This + This. I’ve had 2 MX518s (I had one for 4 or so years, then dirt + abuse made the left mouse button stick a bit) have had the second for a few and it’s still working great. No trouble on any surface (hard/soft pad, faux wood desk, notebooks, etc), programmable buttons, program detection, etc.

I’m looking at the R.A.T 7 by the end of the year (I have 2XL hands, so I want to try the custom sizing feature of the R.A.T). But I’d recommend Logitech in general, I’ve had their generic mice + the MX518, friends have the G5, no complaints on the whole.

Plus, the MX518 is on NewEgg for $40 (could be had cheaper elsewhere, I just love NewEgg + shipping, unless a brick-and-mortar near you carries it. I got my second one at Target, actually).

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: johnyo
item.description:
Meh, my $5 A4tech mouse has lasted for about 5 years now and doesn’t seem to be worse for wear. It’s got such advanced features as 2 buttons and a clickable wheel.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: Shinobi
item.description:
d0z!n0X:

Logitech G9… Its packing 3200 dpi. Best mouse I’ve ever had.

Seconded. It has four programmable buttons, 7 if you include the wheel, which can be pushed in and to the left and right, the wheel can be set to click of free spin, adjustable weights, interchangeable grips. Plus you can change what color the LEDs are on it which is not useful but really cool. It has a nifty on board memory which stores your mouse settings so that you can use it on other computers without installing the driver. In fact, I still haven’t installed the driver on my new laptop.

Read full topic

but maybe I’m just unlucky and they are good.

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: FireTime
item.description:
<3 my Razer diamondback 1st gen. I’ve been using it for so long the silicone coating is wearing thin on the mouse buttons. I’ve had this mouse for some time now and used it for allot of counterstrike gun game back in the day. Never had a single complaint about the mouse. Buttons are the same stiffness and responsiveness as the day I got it.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: Deathmonkey7
item.description:
I have the Saitek PM27 Modern Warfare 2 edition. I wasn’t that fond of Modern Warfare 2… but I don’t care, I got it as a gift and it only has a little ‘MW2’ on the back that even marks it as such. Otherwise it’s a completely awesome looking mouse and works amazing. 3200 dpi, 4 programmable buttons, fits perfectly in the palm of the hand, and has removable weights to get the perfect feel. Also has pretty green LEDs.
Non-MW2 version: https://www.goelectronic.com/SAITEK%20PM27%20BLUE.html?source=googleps
MW2 edition: https://www.amazon.com/Call-Duty-Modern-Warfare-Sniper/dp/B002MZZLNW

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: sudpuzzer
item.description:
I’ve got a Saitek Cyborg Mouse and I like it quite a bit. It’s got adjustable DPI and 6 fully programmable buttons. It fits my hand really nice.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: garrthbarrttinn
item.description:
If you don’t need extra buttons and don’t care about the uselessly large dpi on most gaming mice, buy this thing: viewsonic MU660. It’s an insanely cheap knock-off, but I have yet to have a single problem with it. I think I’ve had it for 5+ months now.

Read full topic

item.title: Gaming Mouse
item.dc:creator: Marb
item.description:
This thread has now become relevant to my interests.

I’ve never had any problems with my cheap $10 Logitech… Current one has polished spots on the buttons where my fingers sit and it still works great… but still, I think a few extra buttons would be nice…
